Ukrainian music and dance have a long history that dates back to pre-Christian times. Folk music and dance are an important part of Ukrainian culture and represent a way for Ukrainians to express their traditions, emotions, and history.

Traditional Ukrainian music is characterized by its use of a unique musical instrument called the bandura. The bandura is a plucked string instrument that looks similar to a lute or mandolin. It is usually played by accompanying singers, choirs, or orchestras. In addition to the bandura, traditional Ukrainian music also features other instruments such as tsymbaly (a hammer dulcimer), sopilka (a flute), and the fiddle.

Ukrainian folk dances are energetic and rhythmic, and they are usually performed in groups. Many of the dances have been passed down for generations and are still performed today in various parts of Ukraine, including at the Skole folklore festival. Some of the most popular Ukrainian folk dances include the hopak, kolomiyka, and hutsulka.

The hopak is a fast-paced dance that requires a lot of stamina, incorporating high jumps and acrobatic moves. The kolomiyka is a lively dance that originated in Western Ukraine and features intricate footwork and lively music. The hutsulka is a dance that originated in the Carpathian Mountains and reflects the region's unique culture and traditions.

At the Skole folklore festival, you can expect to see a variety of traditional Ukrainian music and dance performances, along with traditional costumes, food, and crafts. The festival provides visitors with a unique opportunity to experience Ukrainian culture and immerse themselves in Skole's vibrant cultural heritage.
